awd_titl_txt: Particle Astrophysics with Neutrinos and Weakly Interacting Dark Matter: Borexino and DarkSide
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides base support for the particle astrophysics program at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst to participate in the Borexino solar neutrino experiment and the DarkSide project for the search of weakly interacting particle dark matter (WIMPs) in our galaxy. 

Solar neutrinos have played a crucial role in the experimental confirmation that neutrinos have mass and oscillate. Since data acquisition started in 2007, Borexino has reached its design goal and measured the flux of mono-energetic 7-Beryllium solar neutrinos with enough precision to test the predictions of current solar models. After a scintillator purification campaign in 2011, Borexino is in a new phase of solar neutrino physics with the goal of measuring the entire solar neutrino spectrum. A precise knowledge of solar neutrinos will allow us to understand how the sun and other stars work, test the MSW-LMA neutrino oscillation paradigm and search for deviations from it. Borexino will possibly resolve an open question on the metallicity of the Sun's core, an important piece of information with which to study the evolution of larger stars in the universe. 

DarkSide-50, a dual-phase time projection chamber scheduled to come online in late 2012, will prototype design solutions for background free multi-tonne detectors with liquid argon as active target for WIMPs. A null observation would exclude some of the current leading dark matter candidates. A positive detection would begin to give answers to one of the big scientific unknowns of our times. DarkSide-50 will run with 50 kg of argon depleted more than 100-fold in the radioactive 39-Argon isotope. The DarkSide-50 Argon cryostat is surrounded by a compact, liquid scintillator neutron detector and immersed in the Borexino Counting Test Facility (CTF) water tank instrumented and operated as a Cherenkov muon veto. The Borexino and DarkSide collaborations have a significant overlap in personnel and technical and operational resources. 

Broader Impacts: The Borexino and DarkSide projects provide excellent opportunities for the training of graduate and undergraduate students in applications of software and hardware development, and fundamental physics. The techniques developed for Borexino and Darkside-50 can more broadly benefit technology relevant for medical imaging, nuclear non-proliferation and geology.

por.por_cntn:
This award covered the activities of the UMass Amherst group led by PI Andrea Pocar on the DarkSide and Borexino projects over the period Summer 2012 - Summer 2015, and in part until Summer 2016. Co-PI Laura Cadonati participated in the research on Borexino until Summer 2013, and on DarkSide until January 2015.

Borexino, a large liquid scintillator experiment running at the Gran Sasso underground laboratory in Italy, has been running over the period covered by this award. The main outcomes are detailed below:

BX1) In 2014 it completed a detailed analysis of its Phase I data, reporting on evidence of an annual periodicity of the Be-7 solar neutrino interaction rate consistent in amplitude and phase with the expected flux modulation due to the eccentricity of the Earth’s orbit around the Sun [1]. In the same publication the absence of any significant day-night modulation is also reported, a measurement that enables to confirm the LMA-MSW neutrino flavor conversion paradigm with solar neutrinos alone. 

BX2) Later in 2014 Borexino reported the first direct spectral observation of pp solar neutrinos [2], a measurement that exceeded the originally proposed goals of the experiment. This measurement yielded direct experimental evidence of the Sun’s thermodynamic stability over tens of thousand of years by comparing neutrino energy output from the core with electromagnetic output from the surface. The UMass group has played a central role in the measurement of pp solar neutrinos, with graduate student Keith Otis *14 and the PI’s involved in planning the measurement, performing the analysis and publishing the manuscript. 

BX3) In 2015 Borexino reached better-than-5-sigma significance in its measurement of geo-neutrinos [3]. The data allow to claim some limited sensitivity for anti-neutrinos emitted by the Earth’s mantle, not just from the local crust. 

BX44) In the period covered by this award procurement and commissioning operations as well as detailed sensitivity studies were performed for the SOX experiment, scheduled to search for sterile neutrinos using an intense Ce-144 antineutrino source place just outside the Borexino detector [4].

Other Borexino results include a detailed study of cosmogenic backgrounds [5], a search for charge non-conservation [6], and a search for neutrino signals correlated with gamma ray bursts [7], and a search for heavy sterile neutrinos [8].

 

The DarkSide program is searching for WIMP dark matter with liquid argon Time Projection Chambers. DS-50 is running at the Gran Sasso laboratory, while its successor, DS-20k, is being proposed. During the period of this award, DS-50 was commissioned and produced its first physics data, followed by an initial WIMP search using low-radioactivity argon extracted from underground sources. The main outcomes follow:

DS1) In 2015 the DarkSide collaboration reported on a null, background-free search for WIMPs with the DS-50 dual-phase argon TPC [9].The data showed excellent detector functioning and proved possible a better than 10^7x discrimination between nuclear and electron recoils, a necessary parameter for a massively scaled-up next generation experiment.

DS2) In 2016, the first WIMP search carried out with DS-50 filled with low-activity argon from underground sources was reported [10], confirming the excellent background discrimination seen with atmospheric argon and justifying an extended data collection period with DS-50 , currently under way.

Other outcomes include a study for a multi-hundred-ton liquid argon TPC for solar neutrino detection [11]. The UMass group contributed hardware to the DS-50 TPC, participated in its final assembly and commissioning, and shifting with graduate (Alissa Monte) and undergraduate students. Graduate student Tom Alexander contributed to the successful SCENE side-project to measure the detector response to low energy neutrons at Notre Dame, and to the underground argon cryogenic distillation at Fermilab.

 

The Borexino/DarkSide group at UMass has involved a large number of undergraduate students, with above-average representation from under-represented minorities. Results obtained under this award are published in peer-reviewed journals and were presented at national and international conferences, as well as Borexino and DarkSide collaboration meetings.

 

References:

[1] Borexino collaboration, G. Bellini et al., Phys. Rev. D89, 112007 (2014).

[2] Borexino collaboration, G. Bellini et al., Nature 512, 383-386 (2014).

[3] Borexino collaboration, M. Agostini et al., Phys. Rev. D92, 031101(R) (2015).

[4] Borexino collaboration, G. Bellini et al., JHEP 8, 38 (2013).

[5] Borexino collaboration, G. Bellini et al., JCAP 8, 49 (2013).

[6] Borexino collaboration, M.Agostini et al., Phys. Rev. Lett. 115, 231802 (2015).

[7] Borexino collaboration, M.Agostini et al., arXiv:1607.05649.

[8] Borexino collaboration, G. Bellini et al., Phys. Rev. D88, 072010 (2013).

 

[9] DarkSide collaboration, P. Agnes et al., “First Results from the DarkSide-50 Dark Matter Experiment at Laboratori Nazionali del Gran Sasso”, Phys. Lett. B 743, 456 (2015).

[10] DarkSide Collaboration, P. Agnes et al., Phys. Rev C93, 081101(R) (2016).

[11] D. Franco et al., JCAP 08, 017 (2016).

[12] T. Alexander et al., Phys. Rev. D88, 092006 (2013).
